p.s: The relationship between Macbeth and Lady Macbeth is a manipulative one, stemming from Lady Macbeth, wherein she uses rethoricalrhetorical devices and chooses her words, such that she is able to manipulate Macbeth into doing her bidding while disguising it under his own desires.
That the relationship is manipulative can be seen in the way Lady Macbeth convinces Macbeth to kill King Duncan.

Macbeth seems to be sure he should not attempt to kill the King supported by the imagery I have bought Golden opinions from all sorts of people, which would be worn now in their newest gloss, not cast aside so soon (ll. 5-8), meaning the public opinion about him is currently good and that he does not want it to become worse yet.

Later on Macbeth clarifies his opinion by using the contrast I dare do all that may become a man, who dares do more is none (ll. 21-22), which means he should not take more than he is able to and calls upon his honour as a man.
In order to convince Macbeth Lady Macbeth uses several rethoricalrhetorical and language devices.
Firstly she directly adressesaddresses him by using the word you a lot (cf. ll. 10, 13, 15, 24, 25) making the conversation about him and more personal.
Secondly she uses rethoricalrhetorical questions and imagery to convince him.

The personification and rethoricalrhetorical questions Was the hope drunk wherein you dressed yourself?Hath it slept since?And wakes it now, to look so green and pale at what it did so freely? (ll. 9-12), implies that Macbeth is ashamed and afraid of his own desires and mocks him for this.

The rethoricalrhetorical question Art thou afeared to be the same in thine own act and valour as thou art in desire? (ll. 13-15) as well as the rethoricalrhetorical question Wouldst thou have that which thou esteem'st the ornament of life, and live a coward in thine own esteem, letting 'I dare not' wait upon 'I would', like the poor cat i'the adage? (ll. 15-19), which also contains a comparison with a proverb, both elaborate on this view of Macbeth and are amplified in their way of mocking him, by Lady Macbeth changing her choice of words from you to thou (ll. 13-17).
The imagery and rethoricalrhetorical question What beast was't then, that made you break this enterprise to me? (ll. 23 f.), support this view of becoming King being MacbethsMacbeth's true desire.

Furthermore the imagery Nor time nor place did then adhere, and yet you would make both: They have made themselves, and that their fitness now does unmake you (ll. 27-30), amplifies the argument of Lady Macbeth, that the right time has come.

To further reinforce her argument, Lady Macbeth draws a comparison between herself and Macbeth using imagery: I have given suck, and know how tender 'tis to love the babe that milks me: I would, while it was smiling in my face, have plucked my nipple from his boneless gums, and dashed the brains out, had I so sworn as you have done to this (ll. 30-35), as well as examplifying her sheer conviction with the power of the chosen image.
To reinforce the perceived safety of her plan, Lady Macbeth further uses stylistic devices.

The personification Whereto the rather shall his day's hard journey soundly invite him (ll. 40 f.) as well as the imagery Will I with wine and wassail so convince that memory, the warder of the brain, shall be a fume, and the receipt of reason a limbeck only (ll. 42-45) and the rethoricalrhetorical questions when in swinish sleep their drenched nature lie as in death, what cannot you and I perform upon the unguarded Duncan?What not put upon his spongy officers, who shall bear the guilt of our great quell?, she uses greatly amplify the effect of the arguments speaking for the execution of her plan.

There however seems to still be respect from Lady Macbeth's side toward Macbeth, seen as she stops mocking him with rethoricalrhetorical questions and adresseesaddresses him with you instead of thou again (e.g. cf. ll. 24, 25, 26, etc.), after he asks her to be quiet: Prithee, peace (l. 20).

The imagery I am settled and bend up each corporal agent to this terrible feat (ll. 53 f.) and the metaphor false face must hide what the false heart doth know (l. 55), which means that a liarsliar's face must not show his feelings, both show that Lady Macbeth managed to convince Macbeth and reinforce the effect that she has on him.

So in the end, the relationship between Macbeth and his wife seems somewhat manipulative, since she uses lots of stylistic and rethoricalrhetorical devices in order to get him to do her bidding, but even so she seems to still have respect for him, since she lets him speak without interrupting and stops mocking him after he tells her to be quiet.
